(1) Use a high-performance power supply to suppress interference introduced by the power grid. In PLC systems, the power supply plays a critically important role. Grid-induced inte rference entering the PLC system primarily couples in through the PLC system’s power sources—such as the CPU power supply, I/O power supplies, and transmitter power supplies—as wel l as through the power supplies of instruments that have direct electrical connections to the PLC system. To minimize interference in PLC systems, isolation-type power supplies wit h excellent performance are typically employed for the system’s main power supply.
(2) Properly select cables and implement segregated cabling. Different types of signals should be  transmitted via distinct cables, with signal cables routed in separate layers based on the specific type of signal they carry. It is strictly prohibited to use different conductor s within the same cable for simultaneously transmitting both power supply and signal—instead, power lines, control lines, as well as the PLC’s power and I/O lines, must be wired se parately.

1.3 Failure Modes of Mechanical Components and Corresponding Countermeasures
During equipment operation, the phenomenon where mechanical components lose their intended functionality due to various factors such as design, materials, manufacturing processes, and assembly—rendering them unable to continue working—is referred to as failure. When critical components of machinery fail, it indicates that the equipment has entered a state of malfunction. Machine failures are inherently linked to the failure of mechanical parts. Given the wide variety of mechanical equipment types, along with significant differences in operating conditions and environmental factors, the failure modes of mechanical components also vary widely. Among these, the four most common and representative failure modes are wear, corrosion, deformation, and fracture.
1.3.1 Wear of Mechanical Components
Wear of mechanical components is the primary failure mode for parts. In typical mechanical equipment, approximately 80% of failed or scrapped components are due to wear-related issues. Wear not only reduces the efficiency and reliability of机电设备 but can also lead to premature failure of the equipment itself.

corpus.d61b4238-031b-49d7-b873-6b08788879db:
The rotor of the speed relay is a permanent magnet, directly connected to the shaft of the motor being controlled. The stator is fixed to a mounting bracket, constructed from stacked silicon steel laminations and equipped with a squirrel-cage winding. When the motor shaft rotates, the rotor spins along with it, generating a rotating magnetic field within the air gap surrounding the rotor. This induced rotating field, in turn, generates currents within the squirrel-cage winding—currents that increase in magnitude as the rotor speed rises. The magnetic field produced by these induced currents interacts with the rotating magnetic field, creating a torque on the stator that acts in the same direction as the rotor’s rotation. Consequently, the higher the rotor speed, the greater the resulting torque.
When the rotor is stationary, the stator remains in a stable central position due to the gravitational force acting on the stator holder. Once the rotor starts rotating, the stator experiences a torque that causes it to turn in the same direction as the rotor.

Wear occurs when hard particulates—such as dust in the air or metal particles generated by abrasion—cause material transfer from one surface t o another, or even simultaneous material loss on both surfaces, during relative motion. Among the many wear failure modes, abrasive wear is not only the most common but also the mo st severe type of failure.
Fretting wear refers to a type of wear where localized areas on the surfaces of friction pairs develop fatigue cracks under cyclic contact stresses, lead ing to the detachment of micro-sheets or particles. Depending on the nature of contact and relative motion between the friction pairs, fretting wear can be categorized into two mai n forms: rolling-contact fatigue wear and sliding-contact fatigue wear. In practical applications, pure rolling-contact fatigue wear is relatively rare; most often, it occurs as a  combination of rolling and sliding motions.
Adhesive wear occurs when, at the points of contact between mating surfaces,  "cold welding " takes place, causing material from one surface to transfer to the other during relative sliding.

As the technological sophistication of factory equipment continues to rise, with increasingly complex system designs and broader adoption of mechatronic solutions, production activities are becoming more reliant on equipment performance and reliability. Consequently, the traditional static approach to maintenance management is evolving into a more dynamic model, gradually moving toward advanced strategies such as reliability-centered maintenance and quality-focused repair practices.
Mechatronic equipment comes in a wide variety of types and is widely applied, making it essential to select one or a combination of maintenance methods tailored to the specific situation. When choosing a maintenance approach for mechatronic systems, reliability typically becomes the primary focus. For critical components, implementing condition-based monitoring allows for timely preventive measures. Meanwhile, for equipment at quality control points, it’s crucial to closely track changes in product quality during the manufacturing process and promptly address any detected anomalies through quality repairs. Additionally, it’s important to equip teams with personnel who are well-versed in microelectronics technology, providing them with supervision and guidance while fostering the development of skilled, integrated mechatronics technicians.

2.4.5 Clearance in Rolling Bearings and Its Adjustment
The clearance in rolling bearings ensures proper operation of the rolling elements, facilitates lubrication, and accommodates thermal expansion. However, the clearance in rolling bearings must not be too large—or too small. If the clearance is excessive, it reduces the number of rolling elements simultaneously bearing the load, increasing the load on each individual element, which in turn shortens the bearing’s lifespan and compromises rotational accuracy, potentially leading to noise and vibration.

As shown in Figure 4.2, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and operating principle of an unheated regenerative adsorption dryer. This type of dryer has two beds filled with…
The containers 1 and 2, acting as adsorbents, work by drawing moisture from the adsorbent material as air flows from the bottom to the top of container 1, releasing it into the atmosphere. These two containers periodically swap functions (every 5–10 minutes), enabling the adsorbent to alternate between adsorption and regeneration cycles. This continuous process ensures a steady supply of dry air.

2) Pitting corrosion
When gears are in operation, prolonged exposure to pulsating cyclic stresses can cause tiny metal flakes to detach, resulting in the formation of shallow pits.
Phenomenon: Pitting typically occurs in well-lubricated, closed gear drives. The specific locations are usually near the pitch line, where relative sliding velocities are low, making it difficult to form a lubricant film. In spur gear drives, contact stresses are also relatively high, further increasing the likelihood of pitting.
To reduce pitting, the following measures can be taken: From a design perspective, the gear should undergo calculations to ensure adequate tooth surface contact strength. From a manufacturing perspective,
In terms of engineering, the tooth surface hardness should be increased, and its roughness reduced; appropriate modification should be employed; lubricants with higher viscosity should be used; and dynamic loads should be minimized.

1.2.3 Maintenance System
Maintenance work is not only a technical task but also a managerial one. A maintenance system refers to a set of guidelines established under specific maintenance theories and principles, encompassing elements such as maintenance plans, categories, methods, timing, scope, levels, organizational structures, and performance evaluation metrics.
Implementing a rational maintenance system helps optimize the allocation of human, material, and financial resources, enabling timely preparation before maintenance tasks, ensuring repairs are carried out appropriately, meeting operational requirements, enhancing the technical condition, reliability, and service life of机电 equipment, reducing downtime, and minimizing maintenance costs and production losses due to equipment shutdowns.

Classified by Failure Phenomenon
Fault phenomena can be broadly categorized into the following two main types.
(1) Faults with obvious external characteristics that are easy to detect. For example, significant heating, smoking, emitting a burnt odor, or sparking in motors or electrical equipment. These types of failures typically result from motor or equipment winding overloads, insulation breakdown, short circuits, or ground faults. When addressing these issues, in addition to replacing or repairing the faulty components, it’s essential to identify and eliminate the root causes that led to the problems in the first place.
(2) Failures with No Visible Symptoms. This type of failure is a major issue in control circuits, often caused by improper adjustment of electrical components, mechanical malfunctions, poor or loose contact at contacts and crimped wire terminals, as well as the damage of small parts or even broken wires. The more complex the circuit, the higher the likelihood of encountering these kinds of faults.

Metal corrosion is broadly classified into two main categories based on its mechanism and underlying processes: chemical corrosion and electrochemical corrosion.
Chemical Corrosion of Metal Parts
Chemical corrosion of metals is caused by purely chemical reactions. When the surface material of a metal part interacts chemically with harmful components present in surrounding gases or non-electrolytic liquids, a corrosion layer forms on the metal surface. As this layer continuously flakes off and regenerates, the part gradually deteriorates. The primary harmful substances that react chemically with mechanical components include gases like O₂, H₂S, and SO₂, as well as certain corrosive byproducts found in lubricating oils. Among these, the chemical reaction between iron and oxygen is the most common form of chemical corrosion.

When corrosive media enter these gaps a nd remain trapped, localized corrosion can occur precisely at the crevices. (4) Corrosion Fatigue. When metallic components subjected to cyclic stress experience reduced fatigue strength or shortened fatigue  life—and ultimately fail—due to the presence of a corrosive environment, this phenomenon is known as corrosion fatigue or corrosion fatigue fracture. Corrosion fatigue can cause me tal components to fracture even under very low levels of cyclic (pulsating) stress, and often there is no clear fatigue limit. As a result, damage caused by corrosion fatigue tends  to be more severe than that resulting from pure mechanical fatigue alone.

2.5.6 Assembly and Adjustment of Worm Gear Pair
The worm gear mechanism is used to transmit motion and power between two perpendicular shafts, with an intersection angle of 90°. Its key transmission characteristics include: a high gear ratio, a compact design, self-locking capability, smooth operation, and low noise—but it suffers from relatively low transmission efficiency, higher friction, and significant heat generation, which limits the power it can handle, typically up to P ≤ 5 kW. The worm wheel gear ring is usually made from more expensive bronze, resulting in higher manufacturing costs, making this mechanism particularly suitable for applications like speed reduction and lifting equipment.
Based on the shape of the worm, worm gear drives can be classified into cylindrical worm drives, globoidal worm drives, and bevel worm drives, with cylindrical worms being the most widely used.

As shown in Figure 3.5, this is a schematic diagram illustrating the working principle of a gear pump. When the two gears of the pump rotate in the direction indicated, the oil suction chamber at the bottom gradually expands as the meshing teeth progressively disengage, creating a partial vacuum. Meanwhile, oil from the reservoir flows into this expanding space.
Under the action of atmospheric pressure, oil enters the suction chamber via the suction pipe, completely filling the inter-tooth spaces. As the gears rotate, the oil is carried upward into the pressurized oil chamber.

4. Measures to Reduce Fracture Failure
Fracture failure is one of the most dangerous forms of failure, and most metal parts fail due to various factors arising from metallurgy and part manufacturing processes.
Because all of them contain cracks of varying sizes and characteristics, ranging from atomic-level dislocations to macroscopic cracks visible to the naked eye. However, a part with cracks doesn’t necessarily fail immediately—there’s typically a period during which these cracks undergo subcritical propagation. Moreover, under certain conditions, cracks may even remain stable without expanding at all. Therefore, by implementing effective measures, it’s possible to ensure that parts containing cracks do not ultimately fracture. Strategies to minimize fracture failures can be considered from the following perspectives.
1) Optimize the shape and structural design of parts, and carefully select appropriate materials for the components.
Both geometric discontinuities in part shapes and material imperfections can lead to stress concentration.

At its core, this technique involves repairing damaged parts such as those with cracks or fractures, as well as building up wear-resistant and corrosion-resistant weld layers onto the surfaces of failed components. Its primary purpose is to restore most metal parts that have suffered damage due to wear, breakage, cracking, pitting, or other forms of deterioration.
The advantages of the welding repair method include high bonding strength, simple welding equipment, mature technology, no limitations on part size, low cost, high efficiency, and great flexibility.
The downside is that, due to the high welding temperature, it can easily cause changes in the microstructure, leading to stress and deformation. Additionally, it’s not suitable for repairing parts that require high precision, are slender, or relatively thin, as these components are prone to defects such as porosity, slag inclusion, and cracking.
Welding techniques are primarily applied to metallic base materials, with commonly used methods including arc welding, argon arc welding, CO2 shielded welding, oxy-acetylene welding, laser welding, and more.

3) Causes and Maintenance of Crawling Faults Caused by Hydraulic Component Wear
(1) Wear of internal pump components. Wear increases clearances, leading to insufficient or fluctuating flow and pressure output from the hydraulic pump. When moving parts operate at low speeds, variations in their resistance—combined with the pump's inability to adjust pressure—inevitably result in creeping motion.
(2) Wear of valve components and hydraulic cylinders. As wear increases the clearance between parts, it allows communication between the high-pressure and low-pressure chambers, leading to insufficient pressure. Consequently, under varying external frictional resistance, creeping motion is bound to occur even during low-speed operation. Component wear issues are categorized into two types: normal wear and abnormal wear. Normal wear can typically be addressed by repairing or replacing the affected parts, while in cases of abnormal wear, it’s crucial to identify the root cause and implement appropriate corrective measures.

A single fault phenomenon can arise from multiple underlying causes; conversely, a single cause may manifest in various fault symptoms. The occurrence of faults, their specific manifestations, quantitative descriptions, and detection analyses all involve inherent uncertainties, thereby complicating the tasks of fault diagnosis and repair.

1.1.4 Management of Failures
Equipment failure management is a critical component of overall equipment maintenance. Effectively leveraging the fault information generated during equipment operation—by analyzing data from multiple perspectives and predicting potential failures—and subsequently implementing proactive measures to minimize equipment-related losses are essential for enhancing overall equipment management practices.
Establishing a procedure for managing enterprise equipment failures is the first step in building an accident early-warning mechanism, and correctly developing such a procedure is of great significance. To effectively manage equipment failures, it’s essential to thoroughly understand the root causes of breakdowns, systematically collect data and information on common and typical failures, conduct in-depth failure analyses, emphasize research into failure patterns and mechanisms, and strengthen routine maintenance, inspections, and preventive repairs.

3.1.5 Common Hydraulic System Faults and Maintenance
Hydraulic System Vibration and Noise Fault Diagnosis and Repair
Vibration and noise in hydraulic systems primarily originate from two sources: mechanical vibration and noise, as well as fluid-induced vibration and noise. These vibrations and noises not only reduce equipment efficiency and production quality but can, in severe cases, lead to equipment damage, impairing the overall performance of the hydraulic system and shortening the service life of hydraulic components. Therefore, identifying the root causes of vibration and noise and implementing effective measures to mitigate their harmful effects are critical issues that must be addressed and resolved in the operation and maintenance of hydraulic systems.
Causes of mechanical vibration
(1) Imbalance in rotating components. When motors, hydraulic pumps, and hydraulic motors—components commonly found in hydraulic systems—operate at high speeds, any imbalance in their rotating parts generates periodic unbalanced centrifugal forces. These forces can lead to bending vibrations in the shafts, resulting in noise.

3) Gear Surface Galling
Galling refers to the wear phenomenon caused by the direct contact and adhesion of metal surfaces with interlocking teeth under specific pressure, followed by the tearing off of metal from the tooth surfaces as they move relative to each other.
Gluing types include hot gluing and cold gluing. Hot gluing is used for gear transmissions under heavy loads and high speeds, while cold gluing is suitable for gear transmissions involving heavy loads at low speeds. Gluing typically occurs at the top of the gears.
To enhance resistance to galling, you can increase the hardness of the tooth surfaces and reduce their roughness. Alternatively, you can also use lubricants with higher viscosity (for low-speed transmissions) or those specifically designed to resist galling (for high-speed transmissions).
4) Tooth Surface Wear
Tooth surface wear occurs in two forms: abrasive wear and running-in wear. Abrasive wear happens in open gear drives, while running-in wear typically refers to the running-in process under light loads.

5.8 Fault Diagnosis of Electric Motors and Their Control Systems
Proper Use of Electric Motors
Operating Conditions
Proper selection and correct operation of electric motors are two critical steps to ensure their reliable performance, and proper usage should meet the following three operational conditions.
(1) Power supply conditions: The power supply voltage, frequency, and number of phases must match the motor’s nameplate specifications. The power supply should be a balanced system, with voltage deviations not exceeding ±5% (when operating at rated frequency), and frequency deviations limited to no more than ±1% (when voltage is at its rated value).
(2) Environmental conditions: The ambient temperature at the motor's operating location must not exceed 40°C, making it suitable for use in well-ventilated, dry indoor environments.
(3) Load conditions. The motor's performance should accommodate starting, braking, various rated loads, as well as load variations or speed control requirements.
Ensure compatibility with the conditions; when in use, the load should not exceed the motor's rated power.

1.3.3 Deformation of Mechanical Parts
In practice, it often happens that although worn parts have been repaired and restored to their original dimensions, shape, and fit, the equipment still fails to achieve its original technical performance after assembly. This is usually due to deformation of the parts, particularly
It is caused by the deformation of basic components, which disrupts the positional accuracy between parts and, in turn, affects the relationships among the individual components. Deformation in mechanical parts or components can be categorized into two types: elastic deformation and plastic deformation.
Elastic Deformation
Elastic deformation is the type of deformation that fully recovers once the external force is removed. After a material undergoes elastic deformation, it may exhibit an elastic aftereffect: when the external force is suddenly released, the strain doesn’t vanish entirely right away—it disappears only partially, with the remaining portion gradually dissipating over time. This phenomenon, where the strain lags behind the applied stress, is known as the elastic aftereffect.

4. Methods for Handling Inaccurate Positioning in Inductive Proximity Switches
Proximity switches are primarily used for positioning, and sometimes also for counting movements. They feature a signal indicator light on their rear end, which illuminates when a metallic object approaches within 15 mm of the switch’s sensing area—simultaneously triggering the corresponding input port LED on the PLC to light up. Conversely, when the metal object moves away, the signal indicator light turns off, and the associated input port LED on the PLC goes dark as well.
When performing the inspection, first wipe away any water or dust from the sensor. Then, repeatedly bring a metal object (such as a screwdriver or wrench) close to the sensor's end and observe whether the signal indicator light flashes.

The disassembly and cleaning work did not meet the required standards; additionally, the removed parts were poorly stored, resulting in moisture damage or physical injury—and in some cases, individual parts were even lost and replaced with substitutes.
Hazardousness

(2) Failure during the useful life. This refers to failures that occur within a product's effective lifespan, caused by unpredictable, random factors related to both external loads (such as operational conditions) and intrinsic system characteristics (including internal factors like component failures or structural damage). Since equipment typically operates in this condition for most of its lifetime, the failure rate during this period remains relatively constant. Therefore, monitoring and diagnosing failures during this phase is critically important.
(3) Late-stage failures (dissipation-phase failures). These typically occur during the latter part of a device's lifespan, often after the equipment has been in use for an extended period—or even beyond its intended service life. Such failures arise due to gradual wear, fatigue, and aging of the equipment's components, leading to a decline in system functionality. Ultimately, this can result in sudden, hazardous, and potentially widespread system breakdowns.

2. Runtime Faults
Runtime failures occur after an electromagnetic flowmeter has been properly calibrated and has been operating normally for a period of time. Common runtime issues are typically caused by factors such as deposits on the inner walls of the flow sensor, lightning strikes, and changes in environmental conditions.
(1) Deposits on the Inner Wall of the Flow Sensor. Since electromagnetic flowmeters are often used to measure dirty or contaminated fluids, after a period of operation, deposits frequently accumulate on the inner walls of the flow sensor, leading to malfunctions. These issues typically arise when the conductivity of the deposited layer is either too high or too low. If the deposit acts as an insulating layer, it causes an open circuit in the electrode loop, preventing the instrument from functioning properly.

By adjusting the handle 1 and compressing springs 2 and 3, the diaphragm 5 is pushed downward, causing the valve stem 8 to move the spool assembly downward as well. This action opens the throttling port 10, allowing compressed air to flow through while undergoing throttling, thereby reducing the output air pressure below the input pressure—thus achieving the pressure-reducing function. Meanwhile, a portion of the outgoing airflow enters the diaphragm chamber 6 via the damping hole 7, generating an upward force beneath the diaphragm 5. This upward force continuously acts to reduce the opening of the throttling port, helping to lower the output pressure. Once the force acting on the diaphragm balances with the spring force, the output pressure of the pressure reducing valve stabilizes at a certain level.
Within a certain range, the smaller the opening of valve port 10, the stronger the throttling effect—and the greater the pressure drop.

The AC input circuit is shown in Figure 6.19. As you can see, the main difference from the DC input circuit is the addition of a rectification stage. The typical input voltage for AC input is 220 V AC. After passing through resistor R to limit the current and capacitor C for isolation (which removes the DC component from the power supply), the AC signal is converted into DC via a bridge rectifier. After this step, the circuit operates on the same principle as a DC input circuit.
Figure 6.19: AC Input Circuit
From the analysis above, it can be seen that because the AC input circuit incorporates three additional stages—current limiting, isolation, and rectification—the delay time of the input signal is longer compared to a DC input circuit, which is its main drawback. However, since the input end operates at high voltage, the reliability of the input signal is significantly higher than in DC circuits.

② Apply the sealant to the surface and wait for it to soften (about 10 minutes). Then, use a scraper to remove the softened sealant.
(3) Assembly
① To prevent dust from settling on the sealant surface, components and parts should be installed in place as soon as possible after the sealant is applied.

4.2 Maintenance of Pneumatic Systems
Maintenance of pneumatic systems can be divided into daily maintenance and periodic maintenance. The former refers to the maintenance tasks that must be performed every day, while the latter includes maintenance activities conducted weekly, monthly, or quarterly. All maintenance work should be documented for easy reference during future troubleshooting and repairs.
Routine Maintenance
The primary tasks of routine maintenance include maintaining the condensate drainage system, lubrication system, and air compressor system.
Maintenance of the Condensate Drain System
Condensation in compressed air can cause rusting of pipes and components.

10. Causes and Solutions for Three-Phase Current Imbalance and Excessively High No-Load Current in Electric Motors
1) Causes of Three-Phase Current Imbalance in Electric Motors and Troubleshooting Methods
(1) Three-phase power supply voltage is unbalanced. The three-phase power supply voltage should be checked.
(2) Interturn short circuit in the stator winding. The stator winding sh ould be inspected to identify and eliminate the short circuit.
(3) After rewinding the stator windings, some coil turns were found to be incorrect. In severe cases, identify and re place the faulty coils.
